An interesting idea, not one I have seen before in a stonewall structure.  It could well be better to simply play 8...Nbd7 at once, as the black rook is soon forced off the f-file.
moves.9. Bh6 Re8: While the white pawn stays on c4, black can not contemplate the e5 break.
moves.10. Rfd1 Nbd7 11. Rac1: It soon becomes apparent that this rook is better placed on B1, and that this move simply loses time.
moves.11... Ne4 12. c5 Bf8 13. Bxf8 Rxf8 14. e: This move is important, so as to slow down any f5-f4 ideas from Black.
moves.14... g5 15. b4 g4 16. Ne5: I think this is a mistake, as the pawn that is about to recapture on e5 will become hard to defend.  Nh4 is possible, but 16.Ne1 looks best, as it can work it's way to the f4 square.
moves.18. Qxc3 h5 19. a4 h4 20. b5: I had planned to anticipate the hxg3 maneuver from black by walking my king to e2, and double my rooks on the h-file.  The move played is a serious mistake, as it allows the white position to become severely overextended and highlights the weakness of the advanced white pawns.  20.Kf1! is much better, because when the white pawn is on b4, black has no way to open the queenside so the white king will be perfectly safe in the centre.
For several moves white has had a dismal position, there are no active plans that he can undertake whatsoever.
38.Rb2 is the correct rook to place on the second rank, as it can not be pestered by the black bishop.
moves.38... Rh7 39. Be2 Bg6 40. Rh1 f4: ??.  Both players quite remarkably missed the simple 41.Bxg4!, which leaves the outcome of the game totally unclear.
moves.41. gxf4 Be4+: The rook on h1 is hanging.
